step_1.definition: The study defines the disease mechanism as mutations in DJ1 causing early-onset Parkinson's disease (EOPD), with functional defects including reduced dopamine uptake and altered protein localization.

step_2.assay_applicability: Crystallography (structure) and immunocytochemistry (localization) assays are directly relevant to the EOPD mechanism via dopaminergic dysfunction and protein mislocalization.

step_3.controls_replicates: Wild-type DJ1 was used as a control in cell experiments. The L166P mutation (a known pathogenic variant) served as a variant control.

step_4.statistical_analyses: No explicit OddsPath calculation or statistical tests (e.g., p-values, confidence intervals) were reported for E64D.

step_1.definition: The study defines the disease mechanism as mutations in DJ1 causing EOPD, with functional defects including reduced dopamine uptake and altered protein localization.

step_2.assay_applicability: Crystallography and immunocytochemistry assays are relevant to the EOPD mechanism via structural and localization defects.

step_3.controls_replicates: Wild-type DJ1 was used as a control in cell experiments. E64D (a novel variant with functional data) served as a variant control.

step_4.statistical_analyses: No explicit OddsPath calculation or statistical tests (e.g., p-values, confidence intervals) were reported for L166P.
